entries.message:
http://www.letsrun.com/forum/flat_read.php?thread=5010625

No it's more like "12-14 hour per day workers - how do you get your work in?"

"I can't workout because I have a demanding job" is the lamest of the lame excuses.  I find myself going down that route, and I already know it is not worth it; most *progressive* companies (which I hear are great to work for) are not oblivious to this fact.  Personally I would prefer to kive in a homeless shelter than be chronically constipated, (still) sleep-deprived, riddled with atherosclerotic plaque, obese or at-risk of obesity, and just generally unwell - the status quo for people who can't/choose not to exercise.

If anyone never saw it, here is a movie recommendation / must-see sports film: 

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Without_Limits

I wouldn't call this a hardcore running flick...it's just a mainstream sports film, in the vein of "Rocky" or "Field of Dreams".  Just an excellent (and very underrated) film.  I like the Pre in this movie much more than the real Pre, who is at best very overrated.

Really miss this guy's amazing blog (which was really only active from 2007-2009): http://www.duncanlarkin.com.  Some of his writing was almost like something you'd expect to read in the New Yorker.  

Now it's password-protected (but active? It's not really a blog then, if no one else can read it).
The beautiful Anna Pierce.  Love this pic, I'd have to say.

Back in the day, when I first moved to NYC, I used go watch Olympians at a world-class track meet every January for $40 per ticket. 

Now I can't decide on whether to get tickets for Millrose Games, boxing, or Lady Gaga at MSG.  I don't have $400 to blow on the latter, and Millrose is no longer even AT the Garden, and it seems there are only boxing matches there about twice per year.

Had a slight epiphany about the whole Lance Armstrong fiasco on tonight's run: 

If Lance was taking steroids his entire career, then his T was abnormally elevated for all of those years. That kind of sustained hormonal imbalance can't be good for you; so why wouldn't the synthetic T, or whatever he was on, have *caused* his testicular cancer.  Duh, but when Oprah asked about this, Lance didn't say, "Of course it did.", so I assume the exact medical cause may still be uncertain.

Never tried this, but I am very fond of Kale:

http://www.theholykale.com/2013/01/kale-kleanse-juice-recipe/

If anyone never had it, the regular green Kale leaf is not very different from baby spinach.  If you don't eat the stems (which are bitter), it is mild, and blends well with almost any sugary, high-glycemic fruit I suspect, although to date I have only tried bananas and mangoes.

If you blend kale with an extremely ripe yellow (or ideally, red) banana, it will taste mostly like banana.

Wrote a very simple, but cool client for DailyMile anyone can use/improve:

https://github.com/jtarleton/dailymile/blob/master/DailyMile.class.php
Will be tuning in to watch Lance Armstrong tonight on OPRAH.com

Lady Gaga is getting heavy again goddammit - she has undoubtedly been skipping dance practice.  She doesn't need to be in "Born This Way" shape every day of the year, but I think she should definitely aspire to stay in "Eh Eh Nothing I Can Say" shape, which I think is her natural balance.

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/15/sports/cycling/lance-armstrong-admits-doping-and-says-he-will-testify-against-cycling-officials.html?hp&_r=0

Never did like Lance, but he is not my least favorite athlete (that would be Mike Tyson)

This is great, from "Life Is Not a Spectator Sport" ( http://georgesheehan.com/essays/essay17.html ):  "Should a spectator pass all these physical and mental and emotional tests, he still has another supreme challenge to his integrity. He is part of a crowd, part of a mob. He is with those the coach in The Games called, "The nothingmen, those oafs in the stands filling their bellies."
Joined this: http://www.nyrr.org  - now I just need to take up running.
